title: 103_hr181
content: The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" is the short title of this legislation. It introduces a new guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for individuals who become eligible during a transitional period. The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" introduces a new guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for individuals who become eligible during a transitional period. This amendment to the Social Security Act adjusts the calculation of primary insurance amounts for eligible individuals. The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" establishes percentage benefits for individuals eligible during specific years, with decreasing percentages from 1979 to 1983. Excess under former law is defined as the difference between the former law primary insurance amount and the recalculated amount without certain provisions. The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" defines the applicable former law primary insurance amount for individuals based on calculations under specific conditions and modifications. The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" sets out specific conditions for calculating an individual's primary insurance amount, starting from 1950 (or 1936 if applicable) until age 61, with an additional 3 years for the highest total of wages and self-employment income. This applies only if it results in a higher amount than under the previous calculation method. The "Notch Baby Act of 1993" specifies conditions for calculating an individual's primary insurance amount until age 61, with an additional 3 years for the highest total of wages and self-employment income, if it results in a higher amount than the previous method. The amendments made by the "Notch Baby Act of 1993" are effective as if they were part of the Social Security Amendments of 1977, with no benefit increases before January 1994. Recomputation of benefits is required for individuals entitled to benefits in December 1987 based on specific criteria outlined in the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will recalculate the primary insurance amount for individuals entitled to benefits in December 1987, taking into account the amendments made by the Social Security Amendments of 1977.
